issues.title: need to close the term thing (see list issues in the draft)
issues.author: boucadair
issues.body:
*  The terms of ‘digital twin network’ and ‘network digital twin’
  should be clarified.

comments.author: billwuqin
comments.body: It was discussed in recently nmrg interim meeting, it was agreed to change digital twin network into network digital twin.

comments.author: boucadair
comments.body: Thanks Qin. See the PR to fix that.

issues.title: Sample Application Scenarios
issues.author: boucadair
issues.body:
*  In section of 'Sample Application Scenarios', to dig deeper into
  one or two use cases.

is this one still pending?

comments.author: billwuqin
comments.body: Do we have intent translation, sadbox use case? How NDT elements are related to use cases? These issues are raised in recent interim meeting.

comments.author: billwuqin
comments.body: Fixed in https://github.com/cheneyzhoucheng/network-digital-twin/commit/c649a164ef46ab3a31c5fa1239e9e9efc3ffaaf2

comments.author: billwuqin
comments.body:
Can we see digial twin as a tool
"
digital twins are a powerful tool for scenario planning, impact analysis, and change management. This powerful combination allows network maintenance engineer or network designer to test and model optimisation strategies in a risk-free environment, ensuring that only the most effective changes are implemented in the real network. Digital twins also play a crucial role in root cause analysis, providing a sandbox for testing hypotheses and validating the outcomes of data-driven insights without impacting end users. 
"

comments.author: billwuqin
comments.body:
My suggested the scope for Network digital twin concept as follows:
1. Introduction
2. Terminology
3. Introduction of Concept
4. Characteristics of Network Digital Twin
5. Network Digital Twin: Functionality
6. Lifecycle
7. IANA Consideration
8. Security Consideration
9. Informative References
We can consider to separate how network digital twin can be integrated into the management sytem as a second document.

comments.author: boucadair
comments.body: I don't get the comment. Is there a concern to separate the reference arch vs. concept?

comments.author: billwuqin
comments.body:
yes, the comment is from Interim meeting,  Chris debate we are working on controller architecture, he think model architecture can be used in other SDOs, it was incidated by nmrg chairs, this draft could be split into two documents,  to achieve this, a new design team should be setup to faciliate discussing this work.
See his slides proposed in the interim and previous IETF:
https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/slides-interim-2024-nmrg-01-sessa-proposed-modifications-to-dtn-concept-and-architecture-draft/

comments.author: billwuqin
comments.body:
Data, Model, Mapping, Interface are four NDT characterisitcs or four phase of NDT lifecycle management?
where do we position emulation?

comments.author: boucadair
comments.body:
> Data, Model, Mapping, Interface are four NDT characterisitcs or four phase of NDT lifecycle management?

These are not phases.

> where do we position emulation?

emulate/control/diag/etc. are core functions of the twin engine.

comments.author: billwuqin
comments.body: This is something Chris argue about in the interim.  the question is do we develop new network management platform with digital twin integrated, or do we develop network digital twin component?

comments.author: cfjanz
comments.body: I don't understand how it makes sense to call a range of functions as broad as emulation, diagnosis, control, "etc." as a "core functions" of an engine. It's tantamount to saying an NDT does anything and everything. Doesn't it make more sense to talk about NDT core functions that are closer to emulation/modeling based on network data, and then show how those core functions can be composed with other functions, to construct progressively more complex engines that serve different applications?

comments.author: billwuqin
comments.body:
Already clarified in section 3.3, quote text as follows:
"
Note: Real-time interaction is not always mandatory for all twins. When testing some configuration changes or trying some innovative techniques, the digital twins can behave as a simulation platform without the need of real time telemetry data. And even in this scenario, it is better to have interactive mapping capability so that the validated changes can be tested in real network whenever required by the testers. In most other cases (e.g., network optimization, network fault recovery), real-time interaction between virtual and real network is mandatory. This way, network digital twin can help achieve the goal of autonomous network or self-driven network.
"

issues.title: Clarification on Bi-directional interaction
issues.author: cheneyzhoucheng
issues.body:
- It is not possible or necessary to 'synchronize' all twin states or flows to physical entity. 
- Bi-directional interaction means that: data/states/flows reported or collected from physical to twin, and configure changes or 'necessary' data sent from twin to physical.

comments.author: billwuqin
comments.body: Clarified in https://github.com/cheneyzhoucheng/network-digital-twin/commit/efab85d6d080deab03c15417978f1e0a7c55e6dc

comments.author: boucadair
comments.body:
> * It is not possible or necessary to 'synchronize' all twin states or flows to physical entity.

@billwuqin, I suggest we add an explicit sentence to indicate that "the mirroring pace and scope" should be controlled for a given twin instance.

comments.author: billwuqin
comments.body: Good comment, we haven't explored  mirroring pace and scope.  I think mirroring pace and scope needs to be further expanded.

issues.title: Architecture update on Figure 2
issues.author: cheneyzhoucheng
issues.body:
- Inner closed-loop: iterative simulation and verification in twin layer. Outer closed-loop validation and optimization.
- Orchestration for models and resources can be included in NDT mgmt module 
- etc.

comments.author: billwuqin
comments.body: Related to scope of NDT. We need to decide how to separate network digital twin as a tool from network managemet sytem or orchestrator

comments.author: cfjanz
comments.body: Sorry for jumping in late. As you know, my "criticisms" were that the NDT was too closely identified functionally as a controller, and that the presentation of architecture left major gaps between the modeling function and the remainder (e.g., inner and outer closed loops were not discussed or depicted). That said, I think the presentation and discussion at Brisbane show we do in fact have a pretty close conceptual view. You proposed there to reorient the draft toward "concept only" and in fact Colin advised that IRTF should not get into architecture; I think that's a little over the top but in any case.

comments.author: cfjanz
comments.body: I think it is possible to split the difference, by describing architecture on a high level, conceptual basis. Describe a core function based on data and modeling; then describe the composition of closed loops using that core function plus others; then describe how those closed loops can be used in automation architectures (some of which might be controllers, some might be limited to planning and management, etc.) In this description, I think it is easiest to call the "core function" the NDT (full stop), but you can call it the NDT core functions if you still prefer some ambiguity. Once that's done, it is easy to consider use cases.

comments.author: cfjanz
comments.body: If you like this idea we can discuss a matching outline and what content would need change or addition.

issues.title: Figure 2
issues.author: cfjanz
issues.body:
All – I would like to raise an issue. As far as I am concerned, there is only one major problem with the latest draft – there is nothing else from my perspective that isn’t adequately characterized as minor wordsmithing as part of a final editorial pass.

That major problem is the continued presence of Figure 2. This figure was the primary source of the issues expressed by those I represented in feedback. It has to go. 

Please let me restate the issue. The first problem generated by Figure 2 is that it tells the world that an NDT is a controller. The second, connected, problem is it conflicts with the other NDT use cases. And a third serious problem is that the Figure was incomplete – a lot of functionality needed to make a controller, beyond the highlighted data and modeling functions, was missing from the picture and not even mentioned in the text (e.g. the closed loops – inner and outer, intent translation, etc.) 

The point of the feedback is that it is better to consider an intent-driven controller as a use case of an NDT. Seeing it that way resolves all the problems. The data, modeling functions, and the functional management of both, are what are common to every NDT use case - and also the totality of what is now described in section 7. So call that the NDT. In any given use case, you have to combine these functions – the NDT - with a use case-dependent set of other functions. That is what section 8 addresses: and Figure 3 – which was intended to replace Figure 2 - illustrates this for the case of an intent-driven controller. 

This gets you out of having to think about a bunch of different, use case-dependent types or flavors of NDTs.

If we can agree on this change I think we can wrap up quickly.

comments.author: danielkinguk
comments.body: We could remove the term 'Intent' and replace 'Control' with 'Output,' leaving just 'Input' and 'Output' for the interfaces in Figure 2. This approach works well since it reflects a conceptual architecture rather than an implementation-specific design. This naturally leads into Figure 3, which takes the NDT concept and presents an applied example combined with a Controller, where 'Input' now represents an Intent and 'Output' functions as a control mechanism. Other examples of applied NDT might include planning and sensitivity analyses, where the input and output interfaces may differ again.

comments.author: billwuqin
comments.body:
Here is the proposed changes, which mistakely has already been incorporated in
https://github.com/cheneyzhoucheng/network-digital-twin/commit/5bca6a1c7f6246473976055bcc98fc1b0446997
please speak out if you have different view.

comments.author: boucadair
comments.body:
> We could remove the term 'Intent' and replace 'Control' with 'Output,' leaving just 'Input' and 'Output' for the interfaces in Figure 2

I checked the main copy and saw that changes were made vs the public version (sorry for missing that as I was out of office for more than 3 weeks). 

The input/output interfaces seem to be unidirectional while they shouldn't.

comments.author: danielkinguk
comments.body:
Hi Med, 

Based on the feedback from Chris and the ETSI ZSM team, it's been suggested that the conceptual figure should avoid terms that imply how an NDT might be used. The original Figure 2, which includes "Intent" and "Control" as inputs/outputs, might lead readers to believe that a Controller is always required when using NDTs. However, there are scenarios where NDTs might not involve a Controller at all.

comments.author: billwuqin
comments.body:
Hi, Dan, Med, Cheng, Chris:
We need to agree whether input/output interface should be bidirctional? I have seen Med's proposed changes
https://github.com/cheneyzhoucheng/network-digital-twin/pull/32/files/d1284648b4dfe202f59bb06e7fd5f4129c480407

comments.author: danielkinguk
comments.body: Thanks Qin, Med. Bi-directional makes sense to me.

comments.author: cfjanz
comments.body:
It depends how you define the interfaces. I don’t see why data to the NDT … to give it scenario for modeling … would be bidirectional. I also don’t see why an interface providing results of scenario assessment/modeling by an NDT should be bi-directional. I think Med is still thinking of NDT as full use case implementations, especially a controller that somehow magically synchs bidirectionally between virtual and real.

comments.author: boucadair
comments.body:
> Hi Med,
> 
> Based on the feedback from Chris and the ETSI ZSM team, it's been suggested that the conceptual figure should avoid terms that imply how an NDT might be used. The original Figure 2, which includes "Intent" and "Control" as inputs/outputs, might lead readers to believe that a Controller is always required when using NDTs. However, there are scenarios where NDTs might not involve a Controller at all.

Thanks Daniel for clarifying. I don't see how the need for "Controller" is inferred from the figure but if some do, then better to clarify and avoid confusion. Thanks.

comments.author: cfjanz
comments.body:
It’s not that readers inferred the need for a controller, it’s that readers inferred that the NDT IS a controller. The box labelled NDT ingests intent and issues control to the network. What do you call something that does that, if not a controller?

Best

comments.author: billwuqin
comments.body:
> Thanks Qin, Med. Bi-directional makes sense to me.

To me, bidirection can be further break down into one input, one output, therefore I am wondering if we see NDT as blackbox, I am wondering whether we only allow two inputs, two output, it seems the input interface can be break down into a set of sub input interface while the output interface can be breakdown into multiple sub output interfaces, so the relation between input and output can be M:N.

comments.author: billwuqin
comments.body: I think we really need to see NDT as simulation platform which can be nature portion of analytics platform, in some implementation cases we can see NDT coordiinate with control to perform policy control on specific network elements, therefore make NDT decoupling from controller, more modular make senses to me.

comments.author: cfjanz
comments.body:
Exactly. Anything else is conflating NDT with use cases of NDT, and makes understanding clearly what an NDT is, let alone any comprehensible functional architectural representation, somewhere between difficult and impossible.

comments.author: cheneyzhoucheng
comments.body:
Hi All, here are some points based on your discussion. 
1, NDT is a platform/system, which is much more than ‘a controller’. 
2, I agree with current changes on Figure 2, which leaves only NDT part. 
2, If ‘Input interface’ and ‘outer interface’ still has any confusion on ‘controller’, we can change them to ‘Input’ and ‘Output’. Output can be analysis reports, warning messages, or optimization policies, which not always needs to be delivered to physical network.
@danielkinguk @boucadair @billwuqin @dr2lopez @cfjanz

comments.author: billwuqin
comments.body: To consistent with 5 elements defined in figure 1, I think we can keep using input/output interface, in addition, we can allow multiple input, multiple output interfaces. I have submitted PR for this change. Please review

comments.author: cfjanz
comments.body: I think Sections 7 and 8 are good, much clearer than before. I've given the other Sections a re-read as well, from my perspective at most there are some extremely minor nits in Section 5, which are basically residual harmonizations to the changes made in Section 7. I'll get back with that, but otherwise, I think the issues raised have been resolved and the document is better for it. Thank you for bearing with me.

comments.author: boucadair
comments.body:
> To consistent with 5 elements defined in figure 1, I think we can keep using input/output interface, in addition, we can allow multiple input, multiple output interfaces. I have submitted PR for this change. Please review

Thanks Qin


```suggestion
The role and utility of NDT may be represented architecturally by following
```

```suggestion
similar principles, e.g., {{ETSI-GS-ZSM-015}} or {{?RFC8969}}. As described in Section 7, an
```

```suggestion
components then work in composition with other functions or services
```

```suggestion
to deliver an overall functional architecture matching specific NDT use cases.
```

```suggestion
For example: an NDT instance may be used as a core element of an intent-drive network controller.
```

```suggestion
In such as case, an "outer" closed-loop (or, intent-assurance closed-loop) would detect
```

```suggestion
gaps between target service objectives set by intents and actual observed service characteristics,
```

```suggestion
find and proposed candidate mitigation solutions to soften the observed deviation, and drive the enforcement of the mitigation in the network.
```

```suggestion
Finding such mitigations would rely on multiple "inner loops" that include an NDT: for example,
```

```suggestion
NDT acting as a "sandbox" in virtual space, and the process might be iterated until
```

```suggestion
a satisfactory solution is found. At that point, the selected mitigation is passed
```

```suggestion
In such a case, an "outer" closed-loop (or, intent-assurance closed-loop) would detect
```

```suggestion
# A Sample NDT Realization
```

- Contributor Section.
- Additional acknowledgement.

pulls.title: Generalized 4 external interface into 2 abstract interfaces
pulls.author: billwuqin

comments.author: billwuqin
comments.body:
https://github.com/cheneyzhoucheng/network-digital-twin/commit/5bca6a1c7f6246473976055bcc98fc1b04469979
This proposed changes are used to address #31 
I mistakely incorporate the changes without requesting review, please review and provide feedback.

comments.author: cfjanz
comments.body:
This: “The input and output interfaces might vary as a function of the specific NDT use case”

Is tantamount to saying that what an NDT is, and does, is use case-dependent…. So that you need to define a different NDT independently for every use case. If you have different interfaces, you must also have different functions that stand behind those interfaces (e.g. if you have an NDT-as-controller as in current Figure 2, you must have intent translation, inner and outer closed loop, control and orchestration functions, etc. If you have an NDT for AI training, or personnel training, or visualization, or optimization … different interfaces AND different functions).

Why isn’t it easier and more sensible to have ONE definition of NDT? And then you build use cases by associating use case-dependent further functions with the NDT?

Chris


From: Med ***@***.***>
Sent: Tuesday, September 10, 2024 9:11 AM
To: cheneyzhoucheng/network-digital-twin ***@***.***>
Cc: Christopher Janz ***@***.***>; Review requested ***@***.***>
Subject: Re: [cheneyzhoucheng/network-digital-twin] Generalized 4 external interface into 2 abstract interfaces (PR #32)


@boucadair commented on this pull request.

________________________________

In draft-irtf-nmrg-network-digital-twin-arch.md<https://github.com/cheneyzhoucheng/network-digital-twin/pull/32#discussion_r1751921051>:

> @@ -846,7 +846,7 @@ It can include both physical entities and some virtual entities (e.g., vSwitches

 traffic and provide actual network services.

 All or subset of network elements in the real network deliver network data, directly or through other systems, to

 the NDT, through appropriate input interfaces. Network elements may receive control inputs, through specific output interfaces,

-from operations systems in which NDTs play a role.

+from operations systems in which NDTs play a role. The input interfaces and output interfaces might vary in functional NDT use cases.
⬇️ Suggested change

-from operations systems in which NDTs play a role. The input interfaces and output interfaces might vary in functional NDT use cases.

+from operations systems in which NDTs play a role. The input and output interfaces might vary as a function of the specific NDT use case. Note that these interfaces are bidirectional interfaces.

—
Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub<https://github.com/cheneyzhoucheng/network-digital-twin/pull/32#pullrequestreview-2292455687>, or unsubscribe<https://github.com/notifications/unsubscribe-auth/AZ6FI5A3WZEIXTVBMT4ARNTZV3VXRAVCNFSM6AAAAABN6V5L7GVHI2DSMVQWIX3LMV43YUDVNRWFEZLROVSXG5CSMV3GSZLXHMZDEOJSGQ2TKNRYG4>.
You are receiving this because your review was requested.Message ID: ***@***.******@***.***>>

comments.author: cfjanz
comments.body:
This said, it’s the Figure (Figure 2) more than detailed text like “the input and output interfaces may vary …” hey, they might, we’re not saying how, and we’re not defining interfaces in detail) that is the problem. Figure 3 and section 8 were added to show and explain more fulsomely the use case that Figure 2 was suggesting (“NDT as controller” -> NDT in/supporting controller). Personally I’d still rather just get rid of Figure 2. Given Figure 1, the current Section 7 text, and Figure 3/Section 8, I don’t think Figure 2 adds anything but confusion.

Chris


From: Christopher Janz

This: “The input and output interfaces might vary as a function of the specific NDT use case”

Is tantamount to saying that what an NDT is, and does, is use case-dependent…. So that you need to define a different NDT independently for every use case. If you have different interfaces, you must also have different functions that stand behind those interfaces (e.g. if you have an NDT-as-controller as in current Figure 2, you must have intent translation, inner and outer closed loop, control and orchestration functions, etc. If you have an NDT for AI training, or personnel training, or visualization, or optimization … different interfaces AND different functions).

Why isn’t it easier and more sensible to have ONE definition of NDT? And then you build use cases by associating use case-dependent further functions with the NDT?

Chris
